articles.headline: Helmut Kohl, Chancellor Who Reunited Germany, Dies at 87
articles.snippet: Mr. Kohl held the post for 16 years, from 1982 to 1998, longer than any German leader since Bismarck.
articles.abstract: Mr. Kohl held the post for 16 years, from 1982 to 1998, longer than any German leader since Bismarck.
articles.lead_paragraph: Helmut Kohl, a towering postwar figure who reunified Germany after 45 years of Cold War antagonism, propelled a deeply held vision of Europe’s integration and earned plaudits from Moscow and Washington for his deft handling of the fall of the Berlin Wall, died on Friday at his home in Ludwigshafen, Germany, the Rhine port city where he was born. He was 87.
articles.byline: By Craig R. Whitney and Alan Cowell

articles.headline: Trump Reverses Pieces of Obama-Era Engagement With Cuba
articles.snippet: The president said he was revoking elements of a “terrible and misguided deal” by reinstating travel restrictions, a symbolic step away from seeking better relations.
articles.abstract: The president said he was revoking elements of a “terrible and misguided deal” by reinstating travel restrictions, a symbolic step away from seeking better relations.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — President Trump announced on Friday that he was reversing crucial pieces of what he called a “terrible and misguided deal” with Cuba and will reinstate travel and commercial restrictions eased by the Obama administration in an attempt to obtain additional concessions from the Cuban government.

articles.headline: Amazon Deal for Whole Foods Starts a Supermarket War
articles.snippet: The grocery-store industry now faces, in addition to overseas competitors, a deep-pocketed rival with a track record of moving customers online.
articles.abstract: The grocery-store industry now faces, in addition to overseas competitors, a deep-pocketed rival with a track record of moving customers online.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shares of Walmart, Target, Kroger and Costco, the largest grocery retailers, all tumbled on Friday. And no wonder.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Minnesota Officer Acquitted in Killing of Philando Castile
articles.snippet: The officer fatally shot Philando Castile, a black motorist, during a traffic stop last summer. Mr. Castile’s girlfriend live-streamed the aftermath.
articles.abstract: The officer fatally shot Philando Castile, a black motorist, during a traffic stop last summer. Mr. Castile’s girlfriend live-streamed the aftermath.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — The images had transfixed people around the world: A woman live-streaming the aftermath of a police shooting of her boyfriend, Philando Castile, and narrating the searing, bloody scene that was unfolding around her.

articles.headline: Meet the Legislation Designed to Stifle Shareholders
articles.snippet: The Financial Choice Act, approved by the House, would require that investors own a huge stake in a corporation in order to propose policy changes.
articles.abstract: The Financial Choice Act, approved by the House, would require that investors own a huge stake in a corporation in order to propose policy changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Wells Fargo recovered $60 million in compensation from two top executives last September, it was a rare example of managers being held responsible for a titanic oversight failure. To meet sales quotas, the bank had opened thousands of sham accounts for customers, so it was only right that John G. Stumpf, then Wells Fargo’s chief executive, and Carrie L. Tolstedt, the former head of its community banking unit, would have to return some of their pay.

articles.headline: Rooted in Counterculture, Whole Foods’ Founder Finds an Unlikely Refuge
articles.snippet: John Mackey wanted to fight off the activist investors attacking Whole Foods. He found a savior in Amazon, a company blamed for laying waste to retailers.
articles.abstract: John Mackey wanted to fight off the activist investors attacking Whole Foods. He found a savior in Amazon, a company blamed for laying waste to retailers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since John Mackey co-founded a precursor to Whole Foods in 1978, he has taken a hands-on management approach to the organic grocery chain. He personally oversaw each step of its national expansion. During a takeover battle 10 years ago, Mr. Mackey used a pseudonym to write anonymous blog posts attacking a competitor.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: In Whole Foods, Bezos Gets a Sustainably Sourced Guinea Pig
articles.snippet: By purchasing the upscale chain, Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief, has a chance to tinker with how people buy groceries — and map the future of the physical store.
articles.abstract: By purchasing the upscale chain, Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief, has a chance to tinker with how people buy groceries — and map the future of the physical store.
articles.lead_paragraph: When big tech companies make big moves, it’s natural to see the news in earthshaking terms.

articles.headline: The Decline of the Baronial C.E.O.
articles.snippet: Corporate giants once had all-powerful chiefs with domains to match. But activist investors and technological change are remaking the executive suite.
articles.abstract: Corporate giants once had all-powerful chiefs with domains to match. But activist investors and technological change are remaking the executive suite.
articles.lead_paragraph: FAIRFIELD, Conn. — They bestrode the business world, or at least the suburban corporate campus, like a colossus.

articles.headline: A Mother’s Death, a Botched Inquiry and a Sheriff at War
articles.snippet: The sheriff called it a suicide. When a state investigator raised questions, he became the investigated.
articles.abstract: The sheriff called it a suicide. When a state investigator raised questions, he became the investigated.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. — Rusty Rodgers did not fit everyone’s image of a law enforcement officer, particularly in deeply conservative northeast Florida. One police chief, well ensconced in the local power structure, expressed irritation over what he called the officer’s “Jimmy Buffett look” — long hair, beard, loafers and no socks.

articles.headline: Airbnb Tries to Behave More Like a Hotel
articles.snippet: Less chatting on the couch; fewer idiosyncratic toiletries in the bath. Pursuing growth, the company promotes consistency among its millions of hosts.
articles.abstract: Less chatting on the couch; fewer idiosyncratic toiletries in the bath. Pursuing growth, the company promotes consistency among its millions of hosts.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — For nine years, Jill Bishop enjoyed the camaraderie of renting out her spare bedroom on Airbnb.

articles.headline: Whole Foods Deal Shows Amazon’s Prodigious Tolerance for Risk
articles.snippet: A longtime approach of making bold — and sometimes head-scratching — moves has brought Jeff Bezos staggering success.
articles.abstract: A longtime approach of making bold — and sometimes head-scratching — moves has brought Jeff Bezos staggering success.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joke all you want about drone-delivered kale and arugula. Amazon’s $13.4 billion bet to take on the $800 billion grocery business in the United States by acquiring Whole Foods fits perfectly into the retailer’s business model.

articles.headline: Before the Gunfire in Virginia, a Volatile Home Life in Illinois
articles.snippet: James T. Hodgkinson had a troubled life before he drove halfway across the country to shoot at members of Congress at a baseball practice.
articles.abstract: James T. Hodgkinson had a troubled life before he drove halfway across the country to shoot at members of Congress at a baseball practice.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELLEVILLE, Ill. — Signs of a deeply disturbed family life kept surfacing from the well-kept house with the pale sun awning and the pretty flowerpots off a gravel road here.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz, Sheryl Gay Stolberg, John Eligon and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: As Uber Leaders Step Aside, Arianna Huffington’s Influence Grows
articles.snippet: In the 14 months since she joined the board, Ms. Huffington has been a public voice for the start-up and a confidante to its chief executive.
articles.abstract: In the 14 months since she joined the board, Ms. Huffington has been a public voice for the start-up and a confidante to its chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In April, Wan Ling Martello, the head of Nestlé in Asia, found herself seated across from Arianna Huffington, an Uber director and a founder of The Huffington Post, at the Union Square Cafe in Manhattan.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: How Michael Flynn’s Disdain for Limits Led to a Legal Quagmire
articles.snippet: Fired by the military, Mr. Flynn tried to build a lucrative consulting business. Instead, he sparked a scandal.
articles.abstract: Fired by the military, Mr. Flynn tried to build a lucrative consulting business. Instead, he sparked a scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Michael T. Flynn was a man seething and thwarted. In the summer of 2014, after repeatedly clashing with other Obama administration officials over his management of the Defense Intelligence Agency — and what he saw as his unheeded warnings about the rising power of Islamic militants — Mr. Flynn was fired, bringing his military career to an abrupt end.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore, Matthew Rosenberg and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: Sleeping Sailors on U.S.S. Fitzgerald Awoke to a Calamity at Sea
articles.snippet: After a frantic search through twisted wreckage and flooded cabins for missing sailors, bodies were found in the berthing compartments of the destroyer after it collided with a cargo vessel.
articles.abstract: After a frantic search through twisted wreckage and flooded cabins for missing sailors, bodies were found in the berthing compartments of the destroyer after it collided with a cargo vessel.
articles.lead_paragraph: As an American destroyer cruised off the waters of Japan in clear weather in the early hours of Saturday, only a few dozen of the crew of 350 were likely to be awake: standing watch, keeping the engines running, manning the bridge.

articles.headline: Trump ‘Is Not Under Investigation,’ His Lawyer Insists
articles.snippet: Jay Sekulow made the assertion on CBS’s “Face the Nation,” though he acknowledged that he had no way of knowing for sure.
articles.abstract: Jay Sekulow made the assertion on CBS’s “Face the Nation,” though he acknowledged that he had no way of knowing for sure.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A member of President Trump’s legal team said on Sunday that the president was not under investigation by the special counsel looking into Russia’s election-year meddling, contradicting Mr. Trump’s assertion in a Friday morning tweet that he is a subject of the widening inquiry.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Noah Weiland

articles.headline: As U.S. Adds Troops in Afghanistan, Trump’s Strategy Remains Undefined
articles.snippet: Military experts say that in outsourcing decisions on troop levels to the Pentagon, the president has abdicated his duty to defend troop deployments.
articles.abstract: Military experts say that in outsourcing decisions on troop levels to the Pentagon, the president has abdicated his duty to defend troop deployments.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump made his first major decision on the war in Afghanistan, he did not announce it in a nationally televised address from the White House or a speech at West Point.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: One Ohio Town’s Immigration Clash, Down in the Actual Muck
articles.snippet: A community long reliant on seasonal migrant field workers calls off a welcome-back party, and joins in the national argument over illegal immigration.
articles.abstract: A community long reliant on seasonal migrant field workers calls off a welcome-back party, and joins in the national argument over illegal immigration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WILLARD, Ohio — Migrant workers arrive here every spring to work in the “muck,” which is what everybody calls the fertile soil that makes this part of Ohio the perfect place to grow radishes, peppers, cucumbers and leafy greens. The temporary workers can be seen planting, weeding and, later in the season, harvesting crops that will be sold at national supermarket chains.

articles.headline: The Car Was Repossessed, but the Debt Remains
articles.snippet: Millions of Americans are shackled to high-interest auto loans after a subprime lending spree, and regulators fear the effect on the broader economy.
articles.abstract: Millions of Americans are shackled to high-interest auto loans after a subprime lending spree, and regulators fear the effect on the broader economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than a decade after Yvette Harris’s 1997 Mitsubishi was repossessed, she is still paying off her car loan.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Univision’s Urgent Sense of Purpose: A Newsroom and a Lifeline
articles.snippet: The Spanish-language network is a striking example of a news organization that is meeting the needs of a frightened and information-famished audience.
articles.abstract: The Spanish-language network is a striking example of a news organization that is meeting the needs of a frightened and information-famished audience.
articles.lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — Earlier this year, a rumor rippled through the large Hispanic community in northeast Miami, delivered through the WhatsApp text-messaging service: Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents were hauling undocumented immigrants off to detention centers in buses. The “deportation force” President Trump promised during the campaign had finally arrived, it seemed.

articles.headline: YouTube Sets New Policies to Curb Extremist Videos
articles.snippet: The company says it wants to quickly identify and pull down videos promoting terrorism. It will also make offensive videos harder to find.
articles.abstract: The company says it wants to quickly identify and pull down videos promoting terrorism. It will also make offensive videos harder to find.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — YouTube has struggled for years with videos that promote offensive viewpoints but do not necessarily violate the company’s guidelines for removal. Now it is taking a new approach: Bury them.

articles.headline: Using Texts as Lures, Government Spyware Targets Mexican Journalists and Their Families
articles.snippet: Software bought by the Mexican government is supposed to fight criminals and terrorists. Instead, it is infesting the smartphones of its critics.
articles.abstract: Software bought by the Mexican government is supposed to fight criminals and terrorists. Instead, it is infesting the smartphones of its critics.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Mexico’s most prominent human rights lawyers, journalists and anti-corruption activists have been targeted by advanced spyware sold to the Mexican government on the condition that it be used only to investigate criminals and terrorists.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: For Your Consideration: An Increasingly Lavish Emmy Campaign Season
articles.snippet: Encouraged by streaming services like Netflix, networks are spending heavily to get their shows noticed by prospective Emmy voters.
articles.abstract: Encouraged by streaming services like Netflix, networks are spending heavily to get their shows noticed by prospective Emmy voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent Sunday in the heart of Beverly Hills, Calif., the hordes were ready.
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Dallas Schools, Long Segregated, Charge Forward on Diversity
articles.snippet: One of the nation’s most divided urban districts is a leader in trying to draw white and college-educated families back to public schools.
articles.abstract: One of the nation’s most divided urban districts is a leader in trying to draw white and college-educated families back to public schools.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Michael Hinojosa was about to enter the ninth grade in Dallas when a federal judge ordered the city’s public schools to integrate.

articles.headline: Russia Warns U.S. After Downing of Syrian Warplane
articles.snippet: Moscow suspended the use of a military hotline for avoiding collisions in Syrian airspace and threatened to target aircraft flown by the United States and its allies over Syria.
articles.abstract: Moscow suspended the use of a military hotline for avoiding collisions in Syrian airspace and threatened to target aircraft flown by the United States and its allies over Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Long-running tensions between the United States and Russia erupted publicly on Monday as Moscow condemned the American military’s downing of a Syrian warplane and threatened to target aircraft flown by the United States and its allies west of the Euphrates.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Ivan Nechepurenko

articles.headline: Justices to Hear Major Challenge to Partisan Gerrymandering
articles.snippet: The challengers in a Wisconsin case that could impose limits on a practice that has helped define American politics say partisanship in redrawn districts can be measured.
articles.abstract: The challengers in a Wisconsin case that could impose limits on a practice that has helped define American politics say partisanship in redrawn districts can be measured.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court announced on Monday that it would consider whether partisan gerrymandering violates the Constitution, potentially setting the stage for a ruling that could for the first time impose limits on a practice that has helped define American politics since the early days of the Republic.

articles.headline: After Terror Attacks, Britain Moves to Police the Web
articles.snippet: The country is cracking down on the use of encryption for instant messaging, as well as on potentially extremist material that circulates across social media.
articles.abstract: The country is cracking down on the use of encryption for instant messaging, as well as on potentially extremist material that circulates across social media.
articles.lead_paragraph: After deadly terrorist attacks and a nationwide election, Britain is once again focusing on a controversial plan: to regulate the internet.
